section: Section 1 – Electrical Engineering and Radio Engineering

questions.question_body: What is the name of the energy stored in an electromagnetic or electrostatic field?
What determines the intensity of the magnetic field around a conductor?
questions.A: The specific resistance of the conductor

questions.question_body: Where and under what circumstances does a magnetic field arise?
questions.B: Around a conductor when electric current flows through it
questions.C: Between capacitor plates when electric charge is accumulated in it
questions.D: Between battery poles when it is charged

questions.question_body: What device (component) is used to store electrical energy in an electrostatic field?
What unit of measurement is used for the amount of energy accumulated in an electrostatic field?
What is the skin effect?
questions.A: The phenomenon where, as frequency increases, high-frequency current flows only on the surface of the conductor
questions.B: The phenomenon where, as frequency decreases, high-frequency current flows only on the surface of the conductor
questions.C: The phenomenon where thermal processes on the conductor surface increase its impedance
questions.D: The phenomenon where thermal processes on the conductor surface decrease its impedance

questions.question_body: Where practically does high-frequency current flow through a conductor?
questions.A: On the surface of the conductor
questions.B: Along the central axis of the conductor
questions.C: Through the entire cross-section of the conductor
questions.D: Through the magnetic field around the conductor

questions.question_body: Why does all high-frequency current flow through a conductor practically only in a very thin layer on its surface?
questions.A: Due to heating of the conductor in its interior
questions.C: Due to the self-inductance of the conductor
questions.D: Because the high-frequency resistance of the conductor is much less than its DC resistance

questions.question_body: What is a sinusoidal wave?
questions.A: A wave that decays over time according to a sinusoidal law
questions.B: A wave whose polarization changes over time according to a sinusoidal law
questions.C: A wave whose amplitude changes over time according to a sinusoidal law
questions.D: A wave whose frequency changes over time according to a sinusoidal law

questions.question_body: What is the period of one oscillation (wave)?
questions.A: The time required for one cycle
questions.B: The number of degrees in one cycle
questions.C: The number of zero-line crossings in one cycle
questions.D: The number of oscillations per 1 second

questions.question_body: How many degrees does one complete period of a sinusoidal oscillation (wave) contain?
Why is alternating voltage and current with sinusoidal form most commonly used (including mains voltage)?
questions.A: Because they cause the smallest losses in electrical circuit elements (resistors, inductors, capacitors)
questions.B: Because with sinusoidal alternating current there are no reactive losses in electrical circuit elements (resistors, inductors, capacitors)
questions.C: Because with sinusoidal alternating current there are no active losses in electrical circuit elements (resistors, inductors, capacitors)
questions.D: Because only sinusoidal alternating current does not change its form in electrical circuit elements (resistors, inductors, capacitors)

questions.question_body: What is the most accurate method for measuring the effective value of the voltage of a complex waveform?
questions.C: Representing the wave with a suitable mathematical function
questions.D: Measuring the thermal effect on a known-value resistor and comparing it with the thermal effect on the same resistor from direct current

questions.question_body: What is a square wave oscillation (signal)?
questions.A: An oscillation whose cycle contains exactly 100°
questions.B: An oscillation whose amplitude changes abruptly from one level to another and back
questions.C: An oscillation that crosses the zero line four times during each cycle
questions.D: An oscillation that contains a DC component

questions.question_body: Which factors determine the capacitance of a capacitor?
questions.A: The area of the plates, the distance between them, and the voltage between the plates
questions.B: The area of the plates, the distance between them, and the dielectric constant of the material between the plates
questions.C: The area of the plates, the voltage between them, and the dielectric constant of the material between the plates
questions.D: The area of the plates, the amount of charge in them, and the dielectric constant of the material between the plates

questions.question_body: What is the dielectric constant of air?
What does the time constant of an RC group mean?
questions.A: The time for the capacitor to discharge to 37% of the voltage to which it was charged
questions.B: The time for the capacitor to discharge to 50% of the voltage to which it was charged
questions.C: The time for the capacitor to discharge to 63% of the voltage to which it was charged
questions.D: The time for complete discharge of the capacitor

questions.question_body: What does the time constant of an RL group mean?
questions.A: The time for the current through the inductor to reach its maximum value
questions.B: The time for the current through the inductor to reach 63% of its maximum value
questions.C: The time for the current through the inductor to reach 50% of its maximum value
questions.D: The time for the current through the inductor to reach 37% of its maximum value

questions.question_body: In what unit is the time constant $\tau$ of an RC group measured?
In what unit is the time constant $\tau$ of an RL group measured?
Which formula is used to calculate the time constant $\tau$ of an RC group?
To what level of the input voltage will the capacitor of an RC group charge in time $2\tau$?
To what level of the voltage to which it was charged will the capacitor of an RC group discharge in time $2\tau$?
What is the time constant of an RC group consisting of a series-connected capacitor of 100 µF and a resistor of 470 kΩ?
What is the time constant of an RC group consisting of a series-connected capacitor of 220 µF and a resistor of 1 MΩ?
What is the time constant of an RC group consisting of two series-connected capacitors, each 1000 µF, and two series-connected resistors, each 4.7 kΩ?
What is the time constant of an RC group consisting of five parallel-connected capacitors, each 1000 µF, and five parallel-connected resistors, each 470 Ω?
How much time will be needed for a 0.01 µF capacitor to discharge to 7.4 V through a 2 MΩ resistor connected in parallel, if the capacitor was charged to 20 V?
How much time will be needed for a 0.01 µF capacitor to charge to 174 V through a 2 MΩ resistor when connected to a 200 V voltage source?
How long will the voltage of a capacitor charged to 1000 V remain at a level above 370 V, if the capacitor value is 1000 µF and it is discharging through a parallel-connected 2 MΩ resistor?
How long will the voltage of a capacitor charged to 100 V remain at a level above 13 V, if the capacitor value is 1000 µF and it is discharging through three series-connected resistors, each 2 MΩ?
Which two chemical elements are widely used in the manufacture of semiconductor devices?
What are the characteristics of a tunnel diode?
questions.A: Very high resistance in the forward direction
questions.B: Very high current in the forward direction
questions.C: A region of negative resistance in the voltage-current characteristic
questions.D: A region of extremely linear voltage-current characteristic

questions.question_body: Which special type of diode is capable of amplifying and generating signals?
What is the most common use of a PIN diode?
What is the abbreviation for a liquid crystal display?
What is the internal photoelectric effect?
questions.A: Conversion of photon energy into electrical energy
questions.B: Change in conductivity of an illuminated semiconductor junction
questions.C: Conversion of electrical energy into photon energy
questions.D: Change in capacitance of an illuminated semiconductor junction

questions.question_body: What happens to the conductivity of a photoelectric device when it is illuminated?
What happens to the resistance of a photoelectric device when it is illuminated?
What is an optocoupler?
What basic property of a Zener diode determines its application?
questions.A: A region in the characteristic with constant current at changing voltage
questions.B: A region in the characteristic with constant voltage at changing current
questions.C: A region in the characteristic with negative resistance
questions.D: Internal capacitance that changes according to the applied voltage

questions.question_body: What type of semiconductor diode significantly changes its internal capacitance with changes in applied voltage?
What is the most common use of a varicap?
What is the most common use of a point-contact diode?
What does the parameter $\beta$ (beta) of a bipolar transistor mean?
questions.A: The change in collector current relative to the change in base current
questions.B: The change in base current relative to the change in emitter current
questions.C: The change in collector current relative to the change in emitter current
questions.D: The change in collector voltage relative to the change in emitter voltage

questions.question_body: Which parameter of a bipolar transistor represents the ratio between the change in collector current and the change in its base current?
What is the main advantage of a field-effect transistor over a bipolar transistor?
questions.A: The field-effect transistor has much higher input impedance
questions.B: The field-effect transistor has much lower input impedance
questions.C: The field-effect transistor has much higher frequency response
questions.D: The field-effect transistor is much cheaper

questions.question_body: What is the main advantage of CMOS devices over others?
What is an AND logic gate?
questions.A: One that has a logical one at the output if all inputs have a logical one
questions.B: One that has a logical one at the output if any input has a logical one
questions.C: One that has a logical one at the output if all inputs have a logical zero
questions.D: One that has a logical one at the output if any input has a logical zero

questions.question_body: What is an OR logic gate?
questions.A: One that has a logical one at the output if all inputs have a logical one
questions.B: One that has a logical one at the output if any input has a logical one
questions.C: One that has a logical one at the output if all inputs have a logical zero
questions.D: One that has a logical one at the output if any input has a logical zero

questions.question_body: What is a NOT logic gate?
questions.A: One that has a logical zero at the output if all inputs have a logical one
questions.B: One that has a logical zero at the output if any input has a logical one
questions.C: One that has a logical zero at the output if the input has a logical one (or vice versa)
questions.D: One that has a logical one at the output if the input has a logical one (or vice versa)

questions.question_body: What is a NOR logic gate?
questions.A: One that has a logical one at the output if all inputs have a logical one
questions.B: One that has a logical one at the output if any input has a logical one
questions.C: One that has a logical zero at the output if all inputs have a logical one
questions.D: One that has a logical zero at the output if any or all inputs have a logical one

questions.question_body: What is a NAND logic gate?
questions.A: One that has a logical one at the output if all inputs have a logical one
questions.B: One that has a logical one at the output if any input has a logical one
questions.C: One that has a logical zero at the output if all inputs have a logical one
questions.D: One that has a logical zero at the output if any input has a logical one

questions.question_body: What is the phenomenon where the voltage across an inductor connected in series with a capacitor is greater than the total voltage of the circuit?
What is the resonant frequency of an oscillating circuit?
questions.A: The maximum frequency that the circuit passes
questions.B: The minimum frequency that the circuit passes
questions.C: The frequency at which the capacitive reactance equals the inductive reactance
questions.D: The frequency at which the current through the circuit changes direction

questions.question_body: What happens to the current through a series R-L-C circuit at resonance?
What happens to the total current through a parallel R-L-C circuit at resonance?
Which formula is used to calculate the resonant frequency of a parallel L-C oscillating circuit?
What is the resonant frequency of a parallel oscillating circuit with a capacitance of 40 pF and an inductance of 50 µH?
What is the resonant frequency of a parallel oscillating circuit with a capacitance of 200 pF and an inductance of 40 µH?
What is the resonant frequency of a series oscillating circuit with a capacitance of 10 pF and an inductance of 50 µH?
What is the resonant frequency of a series oscillating circuit with a capacitance of 500 pF and an inductance of 24 mH?
Which formula is used to calculate the quality factor Q of a parallel R-C-L oscillating circuit given the resistive R and reactive X impedance?
What is the quality factor Q of a parallel R-C-L oscillating circuit if its resonant frequency f is 14.000 MHz, inductance L is 3 µH, and resistor R is 20 kΩ?
What is the quality factor Q of a parallel R-C-L oscillating circuit if its resonant frequency f is 7.000 MHz, capacitor C is 63 pF, and resistor R is 1 kΩ?
In what unit is the quality factor of a circuit measured?
Which formula is used to calculate the bandwidth $\Delta f$ of an oscillating circuit at resonance given the resonant frequency $f_p$ and quality factor Q?
What is the bandwidth of a parallel resonant circuit with resonant frequency f = 1.8 MHz and circuit quality factor Q = 100?
What is the bandwidth of a parallel resonant circuit with resonant frequency f = 3.6 MHz and circuit quality factor Q = 200?
What is the bandwidth of a parallel resonant circuit with resonant frequency f = 14.100 MHz and circuit quality factor Q = 141?
What are the main groups of filters according to their passband?
What is an L-filter (L-section)?
questions.A: A group of two inductors and two capacitors
questions.B: A group of an inductor and a capacitor
questions.C: A group of an inductor and two capacitors
questions.D: A group of two inductors and a capacitor

questions.question_body: What is a Pi-filter (Pi-section)?
questions.A: A group of three inductors or three capacitors
questions.B: An antenna matching group isolated from the chassis
questions.C: An equivalent load for tuning the final stage
questions.D: A group of capacitor-inductor-capacitor or inductor-capacitor-inductor

questions.question_body: What is a T-filter (T-section)?
questions.A: A group of three inductors or three capacitors
questions.B: An equivalent load for tuning the final stage
questions.C: A group of capacitor-inductor-capacitor or inductor-capacitor-inductor
questions.D: Another popular name for an SWR meter

questions.question_body: How do L-C circuits transform one impedance to another?
questions.A: The resistances participating in the circuits are subtracted from the load resistance
questions.B: The L-C sections introduce negative resistance into the load
questions.C: The L-C sections introduce reactive resistance into the load
questions.D: The L-C sections cancel the reactive component and change the active component of the impedance

questions.question_body: What is the procedure for tuning a final stage with a Pi-filter to the antenna?
questions.A: The capacitor to the antenna is adjusted to maximum capacitance, then the capacitor to the final stage achieves minimum current through the stage
questions.B: The capacitor to the final stage is adjusted to maximum capacitance, then the capacitor to the antenna achieves minimum current through the stage
questions.C: The current through the stage is successively increased through the capacitor to the antenna and minimum current is achieved through the capacitor to the final stage
questions.D: The current through the stage is successively increased through the capacitor to the final stage and minimum current is achieved through the capacitor to the antenna

questions.question_body: What is an operational amplifier?
questions.A: A differential amplifier with high gain whose characteristics are determined by externally connected components
questions.B: An audio amplifier with high gain whose characteristics are determined by externally connected components
questions.C: An amplifier used in computers for mathematical operations
questions.D: A computer program that calculates the gain of RF amplifiers

questions.question_body: What characteristics does an ideal operational amplifier possess?
questions.A: Zero input impedance, infinitely large output impedance, infinitely large gain, linear frequency response
questions.B: Infinitely large input impedance, zero output impedance, infinitely large gain, linear frequency response
questions.C: Zero input impedance, zero output impedance, infinitely large gain, linear frequency response
questions.D: Infinitely large input impedance, infinitely large output impedance, infinitely large gain, linear frequency response

questions.question_body: What primarily determines the gain of an operational amplifier?
questions.B: The collector-base capacitances in the p-n junctions

questions.question_body: What is the input impedance of a theoretically ideal operational amplifier?
What is the output impedance of a theoretically ideal operational amplifier?
What is the advantage of using an active audio filter implemented with an operational amplifier instead of a passive one with LC elements?
questions.A: The operational amplifier withstands greater overload
questions.B: We can easily purchase an operational amplifier tuned to the desired frequency
questions.C: The operational amplifier is temperature independent
questions.D: The operational amplifier amplifies instead of introducing losses

questions.question_body: What is an inverting operational amplifier?
questions.A: One where the input impedance is very small and the output impedance is very large
questions.B: One where the input and output signals have a phase difference of 90°
questions.C: One where the input and output signals have a phase difference of 180°
questions.D: One where the input and output signals are in phase

questions.question_body: What is a non-inverting operational amplifier?
questions.A: One where both the input and output impedances are very large
questions.B: One where the input and output signals have a phase difference of 90°
questions.C: One where the input and output signals have a phase difference of 180°
questions.D: One where the input and output signals are in phase

questions.question_body: What is a differential amplifier?
questions.A: One that maintains constant output voltage if one constant and one variable voltage are applied to the two inputs
questions.B: One where the output signal is divided equally between the two outputs
questions.C: One where the output signal is proportional to the difference between the signals at the two inputs
questions.D: One where the output has a logical one only when the two inputs have one logical one and one logical zero

questions.question_body: What determines the gain and frequency characteristics of an active RC filter implemented with an operational amplifier?
questions.A: The values of capacitances and resistances built into the operational amplifier
questions.B: The values of capacitors and resistors connected externally to the operational amplifier
questions.C: The voltage and frequency of the input signal
questions.D: The supply voltage of the operational amplifier

questions.question_body: What should the gain of the high-frequency amplifier in a receiver be?
questions.B: High enough so that weak signals exceed the noise generated in the first mixer
questions.C: High enough so that weak signals remain below the noise level generated in the first mixer
questions.D: Inversely proportional to the gain in the intermediate frequency path

questions.question_body: Which noise mainly affects the signal-to-noise ratio at the output of a receiver in the 1.8 MHz band?
Which noise mainly affects the signal-to-noise ratio at the output of a receiver in the 144 MHz band?
Which noise mainly affects the signal-to-noise ratio at the output of a receiver for the 432 MHz band?
What is meant by the noise figure of a receiver?
questions.A: The level of noise entering the receiver from the antenna
questions.B: The receiver's ability to suppress unwanted signals on nearby frequencies
questions.C: The level of noise generated in the receiver
questions.D: The signal level that exceeds the noise level three times

questions.question_body: Which two factors determine the sensitivity of a receiver?
questions.A: Selectivity to harmonic components and linearity of the audio amplifier
questions.B: Its price and availability in the retail network
questions.C: Its intermodulation characteristics and dynamic range
questions.D: The width of the received band and the noise figure

questions.question_body: Which stage of the receiver practically determines its noise figure?
What is mixing?
questions.A: Noise suppression in a wideband receiver by the phase comparison method
questions.B: Noise suppression in a wideband receiver by the phase difference method
questions.D: Processing of two signals to obtain the sum and difference of their frequencies

questions.question_body: What are the frequencies of the signals at the mixer output?
questions.A: Frequencies that are multiples (harmonics) of the input signal frequencies
questions.B: Frequencies equal to the sum and difference of the input signal frequencies
questions.C: The frequencies of the input signals and their sum and difference
questions.D: The frequencies of the input signals and their difference

questions.question_body: What is an intermediate frequency stage?
questions.A: A band amplifier with fixed tuning
questions.C: A filter at the received frequency

questions.question_body: What undesirable effect occurs when a wideband filter is used in the intermediate frequency path of a receiver?
questions.B: Unwanted signals reach the audio amplifier
questions.D: It becomes impossible to receive telegraph signals

questions.question_body: What is detection?
questions.A: A process of suppressing the carrier frequency
questions.B: A process of recovering the information carrier from a modulated RF signal
questions.C: Mixing the received signal with noise
questions.D: Mixing a DC and AC signal

questions.question_body: What is the operating principle of a diode detector?
questions.A: It has different reactive impedance for different frequencies
questions.B: It mixes the signal with a sub-carrier frequency
questions.C: It rectifies and filters the signal
questions.D: It converts the digital signal to analog

questions.question_body: What is a product detector?
questions.A: A detector that requires an oscillator connected to the mixer
questions.B: A detector that amplifies the signal and narrows its bandwidth
questions.C: A detector that provides mixing of the signal with a locally generated carrier
questions.D: A detector designed to detect the products of cross-modulation

questions.question_body: How is a signal with emission class F3E detected?
What is a frequency discriminator?
questions.A: A stage for detection of FM signals
questions.B: A stage for filtering two signals close in frequency
questions.D: An automatic selector of the passed frequency band

questions.question_body: What is the capture effect?
questions.A: An FM receiver demodulates all signals at the frequency to which it is tuned
questions.B: An AM receiver demodulates all signals at the frequency to which it is tuned
questions.C: Of all signals at the frequency to which it is tuned, only the signal with the highest level is demodulated
questions.D: Of all signals at the frequency to which it is tuned, only the signal with the highest level is not demodulated

questions.question_body: Which term is used to describe the phenomenon where one F3E signal blocks reception of another F3E signal on the same frequency?
For which emission class is the capture effect most noticeable?
What is the characteristic feature of an amplifier operating in Class A mode?
questions.A: It is conducting for less than 180° of the signal period
questions.B: It is conducting for the entire signal period (360°)
questions.C: It is conducting for more than 180° but less than 360° of the signal period
questions.D: It is conducting for exactly 180° of the signal period

questions.question_body: What is the characteristic feature of an amplifier operating in Class B mode?
questions.A: It is conducting for less than 180° of the signal period
questions.B: It is conducting for the entire signal period (360°)
questions.C: It is conducting for more than 180° but less than 360° of the signal period
questions.D: It is conducting for exactly 180° of the signal period

questions.question_body: What is the characteristic feature of an amplifier operating in Class AB mode?
questions.A: It is conducting for less than 180° of the signal period
questions.B: It is conducting for the entire signal period (360°)
questions.C: It is conducting for more than 180° but less than 360° of the signal period
questions.D: It is conducting for exactly 180° of the signal period

questions.question_body: What is the characteristic feature of an amplifier operating in Class C mode?
questions.A: It is conducting for less than 180° of the signal period
questions.B: It is conducting for the entire signal period (360°)
questions.C: It is conducting for more than 180° but less than 360° of the signal period
questions.D: It is conducting for exactly 180° of the signal period

questions.question_body: In what mode is an amplifier operating if it is conducting for the entire signal period?
In what mode is an amplifier operating if it is conducting for 180° of the signal period?
In what mode is an amplifier operating if it is conducting for less than 180° of the signal period?
In what mode is an amplifier operating if it is conducting for more than 180° but less than 360° of the signal period?
In which mode does the amplifier have the best linearity and least distortion?
In which mode does the amplifier provide the greatest efficiency?
What does the term modulation mean?
questions.C: The process of separating the low-frequency component from a complex signal
questions.D: The process of processing the carrier frequency with the information carrier

questions.question_body: What is a balanced modulator?
questions.A: An FM modulator whose output signal has balanced deviation
questions.B: A modulator whose output signal contains two sidebands and a suppressed carrier
questions.C: A modulator whose output signal contains one sideband and a suppressed carrier
questions.D: A modulator whose output signal has an unsuppressed carrier

questions.question_body: How is a signal with emission class F3E produced?
questions.A: By modulating the supply voltage of a Class B amplifier
questions.B: By modulating the supply voltage of a Class C amplifier

questions.question_body: How is a signal with emission class A3E produced?
questions.B: By controlling the voltage on a varicap included in the oscillator circuit
questions.C: By a phase detector and filter in the feedback circuit
questions.D: By modulating the supply voltage of a Class C amplifier

questions.question_body: How is a signal with emission class J3E produced?
questions.A: By forming a signal with two sidebands through a balanced modulator and then eliminating the unwanted band with a filter
questions.B: By forming a signal with two sidebands through a balanced modulator and then eliminating the unwanted band with a heterodyne
questions.C: By forming a signal with two sidebands through a balanced modulator and then eliminating the unwanted band with mixing
questions.D: By forming a signal with two sidebands through a balanced modulator and then eliminating the unwanted band with neutralization

questions.question_body: What does modulation index mean?
questions.A: The signal-to-noise ratio of an FM receiver
questions.B: The ratio of the deviation of a frequency-modulated signal to the modulating frequency
questions.C: The ratio of maximum deviation to the highest modulating audio frequency
questions.D: The ratio of the highest modulating audio frequency to the modulated frequency

questions.question_body: For emission class F3E with maximum deviation of 3000 Hz on both sides of the carrier frequency, what is the modulation index if the modulating frequency is 1000 Hz?
What is a reference frequency generator?
questions.A: A device for checking electromagnetic compatibility
questions.B: A device that can generate a specific frequency with exceptional precision and is used to tune other generators
questions.C: A device that can generate the entire frequency spectrum
questions.D: A device that can measure frequencies with 1 Hz accuracy

questions.question_body: With what maximum deviation will the actual frequency differ from the frequency meter display reading of 145 000 000 Hz if the instrument accuracy is ±1.0 ppm?
With what maximum deviation will the actual frequency differ from the frequency meter display reading of 433 600 000 Hz if the instrument accuracy is ±0.1 ppm?
With what maximum deviation will the actual frequency differ from the frequency meter display reading of 14.128 MHz if the instrument accuracy is ±10 ppm?
What do radio amateurs use a frequency meter for?
questions.C: As a frequency synthesizer in the amateur transmitter

questions.question_body: What do radio amateurs use a dip meter for?
questions.A: It can precisely measure signal strength
questions.C: It can precisely measure output power
questions.D: It can measure the resonant frequency of an oscillating circuit

questions.question_body: What type of coupling is achieved between the dip meter and the tuned oscillating circuit being checked?
What is an oscilloscope used for?
questions.A: For observing the waveform of a signal
questions.B: For measuring the amplitude of a signal
questions.C: For measuring the frequency of a signal

questions.question_body: What is a spectrum analyzer?
questions.A: A device used to observe the amplitude of electrical signals as a function of frequency
questions.B: A device containing two detectors - one connected to the amplifier input and the other to the output
questions.C: A device used to observe the amplitude of electrical signals as a function of time
questions.D: A device used to determine the maximum usable frequency

questions.question_body: How does a spectrum analyzer differ from a regular oscilloscope?
questions.A: An oscilloscope is used to observe the amplitude of electrical signals, while a spectrum analyzer is used to measure ionospheric reflection
questions.B: An oscilloscope is used to observe the amplitude of electrical signals as a function of frequency, while a spectrum analyzer is used to observe the amplitude of electrical signals as a function of time
questions.C: An oscilloscope is used to observe the amplitude of electrical signals as a function of time, while a spectrum analyzer is used to observe the amplitude of electrical signals as a function of frequency
questions.D: An oscilloscope is used to observe audio frequencies, while a spectrum analyzer is used to observe radio frequencies

questions.question_body: Which parameter is represented on the horizontal axis of a spectrum analyzer?
Which parameter is represented on the vertical axis of a spectrum analyzer?
What is a function generator?
questions.A: A device that generates signals with different waveforms
questions.B: A device that defines in mathematical form the development of complex electrical signals
questions.C: A device that changes the generated frequency at every moment (also known as a wobble generator)
questions.D: A generator used as a standard when measuring frequencies

questions.question_body: By how much optimally should the reflector of a directional antenna differ in length from the driven element?
questions.D: The reflector is twice as long

questions.question_body: By how much optimally should the director of a directional antenna differ in length from the driven element?
questions.D: The director is half as short

questions.question_body: What is the most common electrical length of the driven element of a shortwave directional Yagi antenna?
Approximately how long is each side of the reflector of a double quad antenna for frequency 29.6 MHz?
Approximately how long is each arm of the driven element of an equilateral delta loop antenna for 28.7 MHz?
What is a folded dipole antenna?
questions.C: A half-wave dipole whose ends are connected with a conductor of 1/2λ length
questions.D: A dipole folded in the middle at a 90° angle to avoid minimums in the pattern

questions.question_body: How can the efficiency of a vertical shortwave antenna be increased?
questions.A: By installing a good radial system
questions.B: By isolating the feed line from ground
questions.C: By slightly shortening the antenna relative to the calculated length
questions.D: By slightly lengthening the antenna relative to the calculated length

questions.question_body: Which characteristic feature of the antenna pattern is necessary for radio direction finding of interfering transmitters?
questions.B: Good front-to-back ratio of the pattern in the horizontal plane
questions.C: Good front-to-back ratio of the pattern in the vertical plane

questions.question_body: What antennas are used for radio direction finding of an interfering shortwave transmitter with a portable receiver?
questions.A: A combination of loop and ferrite antenna
questions.B: A combination of loop (or ferrite) and whip antenna
questions.C: Three or more element directional antennas

questions.question_body: Which electromagnetic wave is horizontally polarized?
questions.A: One whose electric and magnetic fields are in a plane parallel to the earth's surface
questions.B: One whose electric and magnetic fields are in a plane perpendicular to the earth's surface
questions.C: One whose electric field is in a plane parallel to the earth's surface
questions.D: One whose magnetic field is in a plane parallel to the earth's surface

questions.question_body: Which electromagnetic wave has circular polarization?
questions.A: One whose electric field plane has changed its position relative to the earth's surface due to reflection from the ionosphere
questions.B: One whose electric field plane changes its position relative to the earth's surface according to a sinusoidal law
questions.C: An electromagnetic wave that has circled the entire earth
questions.D: An electromagnetic wave radiated by an antenna with a circular pattern

questions.question_body: When the electric field of an electromagnetic wave is in a plane perpendicular to the earth's surface, what is the polarization of the wave?
When the magnetic field of an electromagnetic wave is in a plane parallel to the earth's surface, what is the polarization of the wave?
When the magnetic field of an electromagnetic wave is in a plane perpendicular to the earth's surface, what is the polarization of the wave?
When the electric field of an electromagnetic wave is in a plane parallel to the earth's surface, what is the polarization of the wave?
How is circular polarization achieved with ordinary linearly polarized antennas?
questions.A: Two antennas perpendicular to each other are fed in phase
questions.B: Two antennas perpendicular to each other are fed with a 90° phase difference
questions.C: Two antennas parallel to each other are fed in phase
questions.D: Two antennas parallel to each other are fed with a 90° phase difference

questions.question_body: What is an isotropic radiator?
questions.A: A hypothetical antenna in free space radiating uniformly in all directions
questions.B: In the northern hemisphere, it is a stationary antenna radiating south
questions.C: An antenna positioned high enough not to be affected in its pattern by proximity to the ground
questions.D: An antenna whose parameters do not change when elements are moved

questions.question_body: What functions does an isotropic radiator serve?
questions.A: It is used to compare signals from individual transmitters
questions.B: It is used as a basis for comparison when measuring antenna gain
questions.C: It is used as an equivalent load when tuning transmitters
questions.D: It is used to measure SWR of feed lines

questions.question_body: What is meant by antenna gain?
questions.A: The numerical ratio between the radiated power of one antenna to the radiated power of another, usually a standard antenna
questions.B: The numerical ratio between the power radiated in the main direction of the antenna versus the power radiated in the opposite direction
questions.C: The numerical ratio between the power radiated by the antenna and the power at the transmitter output
questions.D: The transmitter output power minus the feed line losses

questions.question_body: How does the gain of a parabolic antenna change when the operating frequency is doubled?
What is the frequency bandwidth of an antenna?
questions.A: The antenna length divided by the number of its elements
questions.B: The frequency range in which the ratio between maximum and minimum radiated power is 3 dB
questions.C: The angle between the two points of the antenna pattern at which the radiated power in that direction drops by half
questions.D: The angle between two imaginary lines drawn through the ends of the antenna elements

questions.question_body: How is the approximate frequency bandwidth of a directional antenna determined?
questions.A: Mark the two boundary frequencies at which the power radiated by the antenna drops by 3 dB from its maximum value and calculate their difference
questions.B: Measure the ratio of the power radiated in the main direction and the power in the opposite direction
questions.C: Draw imaginary lines through the ends of the elements and measure the angle between them
questions.D: Measure the ratio of the power radiated in the main direction and the power in the perpendicular direction

questions.question_body: How does the frequency bandwidth of an antenna change when we add elements to increase its gain?
questions.A: The bandwidth increases proportionally to the gain
questions.B: The bandwidth increases geometrically proportionally to the gain

questions.question_body: What is the frequency bandwidth of a folded dipole antenna compared to a regular dipole antenna?
What is the input impedance of a folded dipole?
What are the voltage and current at the ends of a half-wave antenna compared to those at other points on the antenna?
What are the voltage and current at the center of a half-wave antenna compared to those at other points on the antenna?
Why is an automobile HF antenna usually connected to the transceiver through a coil?
questions.C: To avoid interference from the car engine
questions.D: To cancel the capacitive reactive impedance of the antenna

questions.question_body: What is delta matching?
questions.A: A method of matching a higher-impedance feed line to a lower-impedance antenna by connecting the line to two points on the antenna element equally spaced from its center
questions.B: A matching method in which the antenna current is forced through a conductor shaped like an equilateral triangle mounted at the end of the feed line
questions.C: A matching method using a three-wire feed line
questions.D: A matching method also known as a Y-match

questions.question_body: What is gamma matching?
questions.A: A balanced feed line is connected to two points on the antenna element equally spaced from its center
questions.B: A matching method also known as a Y-match
questions.C: A balanced feed line is connected to the two most distant points on the antenna element
questions.D: An unbalanced feed line is connected to the center point of the element and another point on it

questions.question_body: What will the standing wave ratio be if a feed line with 50-ohm impedance is connected to a resonant antenna with 50-ohm impedance at the feed points?
What will the standing wave ratio be if a feed line with 50-ohm impedance is connected to a resonant antenna with 10-ohm impedance at the feed points?
What determines the maximum effective radiated power of an amateur repeater?
questions.B: The modulation level and type of emission used
questions.C: The polarization and direction of the main lobes in the antenna pattern
questions.D: The transmit frequency and average height of the antenna above the served terrain

questions.question_body: How is effective radiated power determined?
questions.A: By measuring the output power of the transmitter final stage
questions.B: By measuring the output power of the final stage and subtracting feed line losses from it
questions.C: By measuring the power entering the antenna input and the antenna gain
questions.D: By measuring the power entering the antenna input

questions.question_body: What determines the effective height of an antenna above surrounding terrain?
questions.A: The altitude of the antenna above sea level
questions.B: The height of the antenna phase center relative to the average height of surrounding terrain
questions.C: The antenna height relative to the highest point of surrounding terrain
questions.D: The antenna height relative to the lowest point of surrounding terrain

questions.question_body: What is the effective radiated power from an amateur repeater with 50 W output power, 4 dB losses in the feed line and 3 dB in the duplexer, and antenna gain (relative to half-wave dipole) of 6 dB?
What is the effective radiated power from an amateur repeater with 50 W output power, 5 dB losses in the feed line and 3 dB in the duplexer, and antenna gain (relative to half-wave dipole) of 6 dB?
What is the effective radiated power from an amateur repeater with 10 W output power, 4 dB losses in the feed line and 3 dB in the duplexer, and antenna gain (relative to half-wave dipole) of 10 dB?
What is the phenomenon called that appears in the receiving radio station when phase differences occur in the spectrum of the received signal?
Which type of emission (modulation type) is most vulnerable to selective fading?
At what frequency bandwidth of the transmitted signal is selective fading more pronounced?
questions.C: Selective fading does not depend on signal bandwidth
questions.D: Whether there will be selective fading depends on the receiver's selected passband

questions.question_body: What is selective fading?
questions.A: Fading caused by vibrations of the receiving antenna
questions.B: Fading caused by phase differences in the spectrum of the received signal
questions.C: Fading caused by changes in the height of the reflecting ionospheric layer
questions.D: Fading caused by the time difference between the transmitting and receiving radio stations

questions.question_body: What is the effect called in the receiving radio station when phase differences occur in the spectrum of the received signal?
Which emission class is most vulnerable to selective fading?
Why does the distance to the radio horizon exceed the distance to the geometric horizon?
questions.A: Due to reflection from the E layer
questions.B: Due to reflection from the sporadic E layer

questions.question_body: By how much does the distance to the radio horizon exceed the distance to the geometric horizon?
To what distance is normal VHF propagation limited?
What conditions most commonly make it possible to receive a VHF signal at a distance exceeding 800 km?
In which regions of the world is the sporadic E layer most frequent?
questions.D: There is no difference with respect to geographical latitude

questions.question_body: What primarily causes the appearance of the sporadic E layer?
What are the conditions for the appearance of the sporadic E layer?
questions.A: Changes in the E layer caused by variations in solar activity
questions.B: Sharp increase in VHF signal strength from meteor trails in the E layer
questions.C: Formation of ionized patches at the height of the E layer due to winds and vortices
questions.D: Tropospheric inhomogeneities at the height of the E layer

questions.question_body: In which amateur radio band are the most distant radio contacts made primarily thanks to the sporadic E layer?
What is the cause of aurora and the propagation characteristics associated with it?
questions.C: Emission of charged particles from the sun

questions.question_body: At what altitude does aurora form?
questions.A: At the altitude of the troposphere
questions.B: At the altitude of the D layer
questions.C: At the altitude of the E layer
questions.D: At the altitude of the F layer

questions.question_body: For radio stations in Bulgaria, in which direction should antennas be pointed to extract maximum benefit from propagation via aurora reflection?
To what extent can radio amateurs from Bulgaria benefit from propagation via aurora reflection?
questions.A: They cannot benefit, only stations located beyond the polar circle can do this
questions.B: All radio amateurs (including Bulgarian) can benefit regardless of location
questions.C: Only those located at geographical latitudes higher than 35° can benefit (including Bulgarian)
questions.D: They can benefit only for radio contacts with the southern hemisphere

questions.question_body: At what hours of the day can propagation via aurora reflection be expected?
Which emission classes are most suitable for propagation via aurora reflection?
What happens to a radio wave radiated into space when it encounters charged particles?
questions.A: Nothing happens because radio waves have no physical structure
questions.C: The radio wave loses some of its energy
questions.D: The radio wave increases its energy

questions.question_body: How far apart must two radio stations be that want to establish contact via passive moon reflection?
questions.D: At any distance, as long as both stations can see the moon

questions.question_body: What is characteristic of a received signal passively reflected from the moon?
questions.A: Change in the tone of the CW signal
questions.C: Significant losses at sunrise and sunset
questions.D: The echo is a few Hz lower in frequency than the transmitted signal

questions.question_body: Which are the best days for scheduling a radio contact with passive moon reflection (EME)?
questions.A: When the moon is at perigee
questions.B: When the moon is at apogee
questions.D: When the weather is clear at both station locations

questions.question_body: What is the main requirement for a receiver for radio contact with passive moon reflection (EME)?
questions.A: It must have the 14 MHz band
questions.B: It must have very large dynamic range
questions.C: It must have very low gain
questions.D: It must have very low noise figure

questions.question_body: Approximately how much is the signal attenuation on the Earth-Moon-Earth path for the 144 MHz band?
For which VHF band is the attenuation on the Earth-Moon-Earth path smallest?
Why is the 50 MHz band practically not used for radio contacts with passive moon reflection (EME)?
questions.A: Due to much greater attenuation on the Earth-Moon-Earth path compared to other VHF bands
questions.B: Due to the large size of antennas and high noise level
questions.C: Because the F2 ionospheric layer reflects the signal back to Earth
questions.D: Due to signal absorption by the lower ionospheric layers D and E

questions.question_body: On which shortwave band is an EME radio contact possible?
In which amateur radio band is reflection from meteor trails most important for achieving distant contact?
What is transequatorial propagation?
questions.A: Propagation between two points located at approximately equal distances north and south of the magnetic equator
questions.B: Propagation between two points located on the magnetic equator
questions.C: Propagation between two continents located on the same side of the equator
questions.D: Propagation between two points located at the same geographical latitude

questions.question_body: What is the maximum distance over which radio contact can be achieved through transequatorial propagation?
What is the most suitable time for radio contact via transequatorial propagation?
questions.C: After noon and in early evening
questions.D: Transequatorial propagation is only possible during the night

questions.question_body: To what extent can radio amateurs from Bulgaria benefit from transequatorial propagation?
questions.A: They cannot benefit, only stations located near the magnetic equator can do this
questions.B: All radio amateurs (including Bulgarian) can benefit regardless of location
questions.C: They can benefit for shortwave but not for VHF radio contacts
questions.D: Bulgaria is located at the border of possible radio contacts via transequatorial propagation and, although difficult, radio contacts are possible with suitable correspondents

questions.question_body: What is gray-line propagation?
questions.A: Propagation on the days of spring and autumn equinox
questions.B: Propagation between two points when both are located on the gray line
questions.C: Earth-Moon-Earth (EME) propagation where the signal reflects from the boundary line between the illuminated and dark part of the moon
questions.D: Specific propagation for the 144 and 432 MHz bands at very low solar activity

questions.question_body: If the maximum usable frequency for the Varna-North Carolina path is 31 MHz, which band will offer the best opportunities for achieving a successful amateur radio contact?
If the maximum usable frequency for the Burgas-Vancouver path is 16 MHz, which band will offer the best opportunities for achieving a successful amateur radio contact?
If the maximum usable frequency for the Plovdiv-Tokyo path is 16 MHz, which band will offer the best opportunities for achieving a successful contact?
If a Bulgarian amateur radio operator wants to establish radio contact with a French amateur radio operator at 5 hours UTC in winter, which amateur radio band will provide the best opportunity?
If a Bulgarian amateur radio operator wants to establish radio contact with an American amateur radio operator at 22 hours UTC in summer, which band will provide the best opportunity?
What is the most significant problem for effective use of an amateur shortwave radio station in a car while driving?
What is the correct way to suppress electrical noise in a mobile radio station?
questions.A: All metal surfaces should be isolated from each other
questions.B: Shielding should be done and filters installed where necessary
questions.C: All non-metal surfaces should be sprayed with antistatic spray
questions.D: Series capacitors should be installed in all DC circuits

questions.question_body: How can interference from car engine ignition be minimized when using a mobile radio station?
questions.A: By installing series capacitors in all DC circuits
questions.B: By installing a high-pass filter in the antenna circuit
questions.C: By connecting the power leads to the battery by the shortest path
questions.D: By connecting the power leads to the battery by the longest path

questions.question_body: What is the phenomenon called where signals from two closely located transmitters mix in one or both final stages, resulting in unwanted frequencies different from the frequencies of the two transmitters?
What can result if a non-linear amplifier is used in a transmitter with emission class J3E?
What is receiver blocking?
questions.A: Sharp increase in noise above signal level
questions.B: Sharp decrease in receiver sensitivity when the high-frequency amplifier fails
questions.C: Sharp decrease in receiver sensitivity due to receiving a very strong signal on a nearby frequency
questions.D: Sharp decrease in audibility of distant stations due to propagation change

questions.question_body: What is cross-modulation interference?
questions.A: Interference between two transmitters with different types of modulation
questions.B: Interference from non-linearity of the receiver's audio amplifier
questions.C: Interference from non-linearity of the transmitter's modulator
questions.D: Interference from a strong transmitter radiating on a different frequency

questions.question_body: Which term is used to describe the phenomenon when a high-level signal is superimposed on another signal we are receiving?
How can the negative effect of cross-modulation be reduced?
questions.A: By installing a suitable filter in the receiver
questions.C: By increasing the RF gain of the receiver and decreasing the audio gain

questions.question_body: Which band is most suitable for establishing radio contact from Bulgaria to South America at 00:00 UTC?
During the autumn-winter season, which amateur radio band is most suitable for radio contacts with North America during most of the day?
During the summer season, which amateur radio band during the day is most unsuitable for establishing radio contacts with Africa?
On which amateur radio band is a radio contact via the "long path" with Japan possible in the morning during the winter season?
